snippet.textDisplay:
If black holes create new universes would the matter within that newly created universe be the same matter captured by the parent black hole?


If that is the case, many questions pop up starting with what is the implication for the law of conservation of matter? If that matter is lost from this universe to seed a new universe, then it seems the law would be violated in both this universe (matter lost) and in the new universe (matter gained) assuming the new universe has the same laws.


The same question applies for when our universe was created, supposedly from the forming of a black hole in another universe. Is all matter we see in our universe the matter that fell into our parent black hole? This could fit with what we think we know about the Big Bang and the rapid expansion of the universe, but it also opens up more questions.


If the lives of black holes are so long and they continually capture matter, then would that mean matter is continually introduced into the child universe? Or would only the matter contained in the original collapsing star seed the new universe? (That seems like an extremely small amount of matter to seed a whole universe).


I suppose you could come up with some sci-fi spacetime warping hypothesis that says that children universes formed from black holes have all matter captured by the parent black hole introduced all at once. But in that case, what would it mean for when black holes collide and merge? Where would that matter go in the children universes and what ultimately ends up happening to those universes? Again though, in each of these hypothetical situations the law of conservation of matter seems to be violated.


Lastly, if we theorize that black holes can radiate away over extremely long time periods what would that mean for their children universes?

That is exactly the universe we find ourselves in.

snippet.textDisplay:
Hi PBS Space Time! Is there actually strict definition of the term “universe” in physics? It seems to me that this term is often used in a rather ambiguous way. I’ve always felt that we correctly use the term “universe” to denote the set of all things or the universal set i.e., everything in existence. Obviously if we operate off of this definition of the term, it doesn’t make logical sense to then talk about multiple universes, since in that case each “universe” would actually have to be a smaller subordinate set to the all encompassing universal set (all of existence). I am no astronomer, but as far as I know, we have not identified a specific type of celestial body that is larger in scale than a galaxy.

So, when we have discussions like these about the “universe(s),” if we are not talking about the set of all things in existence, what precisely are we actually talking about? Is the concept even clearly defined? Thanks!

snippet.textDisplay:
The question of what is the internal structure of a black hole remains a mystery as we can not look inside a black hole but there is good reason to doubt that a black hole contains a singularity. The mathematical analysis of a black hole was first developed as a polar coordinate solution to the Einstein equations of General Relativity. It was shown that if you have a distribution of matter lying entirely within a spherical region radius R, then if the region has a sufficient matter density then an event horizon will form at the Schwarzschild radius given by R = 2GM / c^2.


This analysis does not assume a spacetime singularity at the centre of the black hole. In fact if you take the most dense matter item which is a neutron and calculate the size of neutron star which would form an event horizon outside the surface of the star it is 3.4 solar masses and this would correspond to a star of radius 10km. Observations of neutron stars and black holes show that all black holes are larger than 3.4 solar masses and all observed neutron stars are less than 3.4 solar masses. So it is a very reasonable hypothesis to suppose that all black holes contain a neutron star.


Because the event horizon radius is proportional to the mass and the volume of the neutron star is proportional to the radius cubed we can easily derive the characteristics of larger black holes. For example a black hole of 3.4 million solar masses would have an event horizon at 10 million km and the neutron star would have a radius of 1,000 km. A black hole of 3.4 billion solar masses would have an event horizon at 10 billion km and a neutron star of radius 10,000 km. So even for super massive black holes the contained neutron star is quite small in cosmological scales.


So with this description of a black hole there is no room for the hypothesis that a new universe will form inside the black hole.


To address the deeper question of why the universe seems so fine tuned and physical constants just seem to have the right values, it will take a revised understanding of basic physics and cosmology to see why the universe is the way it is:


https://www.academia.edu/5009126/The_evolution_of_the_universe

https://www.academia.edu/5038836/The_Unification_of_Physics

https://www.academia.edu/5927513/The_Spacetime_Wave_Theory



Richard

You will not find any irregularity and disproportion in the system of the creation of the Most Kind (Lord). So have a (meditative and thoughtful) look around: do you find in this (creation) any incongruity or disharmony (i.e., degeneration or falling apart)?"

"And surely, We have adorned the lowest heaven of the universe with lights (in the form of stars, planets, other asteroids and meteoroids). And We have also made (some of them) the means of pelting away (i.e., eliminating the negative effects of) satans (i.e., rebellious forces). And We have prepared for these (satans) a torment of Blazing Fire."

Quran 67:4,5,6

snippet.textDisplay:
I don't believe a black hole is a hole of any sort. Just an object with a magnetic pull / gravity so strong it captures light. If it was a hole why does it have burst that release matter? If it was a hole wouldn't it just constantly swallow things up? I think the burst are like that of a magnetar.
I think the whole black "hole" is nothing more than fantasy. Until we can prove how what we refer to as gravity actually works we will not understand black holes.
More people should check out project thunderbolt and the electric universe theory.

snippet.textDisplay: I think there's a way to resolve the issue of not wanting to rely on the anthropic principle just for convenience, and actually tie together the cosmological selection of universes that are optimized for black holes to form and universes that are optimized for intelligent observers to emerge. That is, if life and intelligent observers are factors that influence black hole formation? Previously on this channel, and many times on another channel called Isaac Arthur, covering hard sci-fi concepts and futurism, the possibility of creating artificial black holes, named kugelblitzes have been raised. (Not sure if I spelled it right.) Now if creating these black holes are indeed possible, then it would stand to reason that advanced space faring civilizations would make them for their numerous practical applications, that Isaac Arthur's channel went into in dept, like power sources, storages, projectiles, engines, gas giant to star converters, stb... If this were the case, then it could very well be, that these tiny artificial black holes would outnumber the natural ones. And if these artificial black holes then give rise to other universes, the combined selection pressure to create universes that can both house stars and intelligent life would emerge. This still doesn't gets rid of the anthropic principle, but at least diminishes it's arbitrary-ness a bit.

snippet.textDisplay: A child grows up to be roughly the same mass as a parent, give or take. A universe spawned from a black hole can only have a fraction of the mass of its parent universe, if conservation of mass / energy is maintained. Each child universe therefore will have less mass, until there isn't enough mass to form stars large enough to create a black hole. It's a dead end scenario.

I don't understand the anthropic principle. I mean, why does the universe seems finely tuned to the existence of life, in particular, instead of anything else?

Think of fire, for exemple. How many physical 'laws' and constants have to be exactly what they are in order for fire to exist? What if the value of Boltzmann's constant was much, much, smaller? Or Newton's gravitational constant was much, much higher? Or if there were 6 fundamental forces? Or if... You get it. There would be no fire anywhere in the universe... I think. Should we conclude from this that the universe is finely tuned torwards the existence of fire? Why I do not see this argument being made, but only with respect to life? What sets life appart from non-life anyway for the purposes of this conversation?

snippet.textDisplay:
Cosmological Natural Selection seems to try to have it both ways. It relies on the correlation between star formation and the ability for a universe to produce complex life, but then it tries to pretend the two factors are independent by assuming that a typical universe with observers will be optimized for star formation the same way that a typical universe without observers. But what if the selection pressure for complex life on all the other cosmological constants is much higher than that on the strange quark mass? Wouldn't we expect the inherent observer bias of our universe to break the assumption that all constants are optimized for star formation in our universe?

For all the faults of the anthropic principle, at least it acknowledges the observer bias inherent to the observable universe and encourages Bayesian thinking about it. Cosmological Natural Selection just completely ignores it.

This is an interesting video. Last time I suggested that if a universe could be created in a lab (I saw Lenny Suskind say this might be possible in an interview), then it's possible that a "lineage" of universes might appear which are selected for having conditions amenable to intelligent life and whose physics experiment would create still more universes. At first I thought Matt was explaining the idea I talked about, which had me feeling pretty smart and/or smug, but then I saw that what he's describing is related but different.

Of course, it's also interesting that we have several possible multiverse theories which don't seem to be mutually exclusive. I need to rewatch the multiverse episode again!

snippet.textDisplay:
I always have a few problems with this theory.
First of all it assumes that a new universe gets birthed the moment a blackhole gets formed. That finite amount of energy would be the equivalent of the energy that the big bang of the new universe contains (assuming energy conservation still holds up trans-universes). However what happens with the mass/energy that the black hole will keep consuming on our end? The theoretical white hole is a possible explanation, however not only have we never spotted a white hole, the influx of new energy is many orders larger than the original energy contained at the birth of the blackhole. If our universe would be birthed from the same phenomenon, we would be able to spot such an enormous amount of extra energy added to our own universe, which we dont.


In addition assuming that our Universe has a finite energy state, which directly contradicts the first point but lets go with it, the creation of blackholes in our universe will spawn very 'tiny' universes. Not only that but there is no addition of energy, meaning the 'evolution of universes' will eventually dim out. Evolution of genetics, aka darwinism, can only exist if energy is constantly added.

snippet.textDisplay: "We know that the fantastic complexity of living organisms is the inevitable result of natural selection." 1:38. I disagree. Natural selection does a poor job of explaining speciation. Explain the Cambrian explosion. Explain the bacterial flagellum. Where did all the extra information encoded in DNA suddenly come from? Your statement sounds to me like, "The Ferrari is the inevitable result of the invention of the horseless carriage. ". It doesn't explain who invented the horseless carriage, nor where the information necessary to change a horseless carriage into a Ferrari came from. We know it came from the human mind. Perhaps in an infinite universe, at some point all of the components necessary to create a Ferrari may have, by chance, fallen together in the form of a Ferrari. But that hardly seems like much of a theory for genetic diversity. Darwinian evolution is a good theory for explaining some changes to organisms, but it doesn't come close to explaining speciation.

snippet.textDisplay:
A few complete layman's questions.
- If black holes produce new universes, does it mean that every universe is within another universe? So some universes that are within the same parent universe could affect another universe (2 black holes interacting with each other within a parent universe), but not with universes that are within separate parent universes? Possibly ones that have a mutual grandparent universe and can interact with each other, but not the grandchild universes? You know like in the tree on the graph on the video, universes from separate branches can't affect with each other, but separate branches overall could on the parent/grandparent level.
- if every black hole is a new universe, what happens when 2 black holes collide? Do 2 universes with their unique properties mix into one somehow? Or is it a new universe forming replacing the former 2? What happens to the properties of the mixed universe and/or the new universe replacing the former 2? What happens to the stuff, the worlds/realities of the former 2 universes? What happens to the black holes and child universes within those 2 collided ones?
- Is maybe the big bang actually the implosion of a star into a black hole and it only looks like the universe is expanding from our perspective, but in reality it's just continuously eating up whatever falls inside from the parent universe? Which could possible also explain the uneven matter/antimatter ratios and stuff - the things falling into the black hole from the parent universe are not in even ratios themselves and hence they kick our internal ratios off the balance?
- is the new stuff sucked in by a black hole in the parent universe capable of changing the constants and general parameters of the child universe?
- is there a top grand-grand-grand-(...)-grand-grandparent universe of all other universes? Where did THAT come from, how, etc.? (I know this is impossible to answer but that question just begs to be asked lol) same as what those other universes are like, whether they have time, space, matter, or just stuff completely unimaginable and possibly unintuitive/illogical for human mind because of it being a product of our universe and whatever happens outside a given universe is just inconceivable for products of that universe? Or is there maybe gradation, that we could figure out what the universes within the black holes in our universe are like, so we can learn what child universes of out universe are like as they are a product of our universe after all, but figuring out what our universe's parent, grandparent, etc. universes are like is impossible? And especially the very bottom arche-pan-universe of all?
- if stuff from the parent universes is being eaten up by the black holes, isn't the arche-parent going to run out of stuff to be eaten up? Is it finite or infinite? If infinite, then how come? How does it work (I know we can't know, like in the previous question)? And if finite, does it mean that at some point every parent in the lineage will eventually become desolate with nothing but black holes? Which means eventually our universe will become so as well and to survive we will need to figure out how to move into one of our black holes that will be able to produce further black holes on the inside and so on? So there would be indeed a sort of a cycle of life of younger generations feeding on older generations, etc. - and once there is nothing but black holes left in a parent universe, what happens to the empty space? Won't it implode at some point, sucked up by the black holes? Won't the black holes within a dead universe at some point merge? And if yes, it it possible that at some point all of the universes would merge back and there will be only the original pan-arche-universe again?

snippet.textDisplay:
Good presentation!
Black holes pooping out universes has been my theory for years. I'm an English major with college math through Calc I and one semester of astronomy.
The cosmological natural selection topic seems irrelevant to black holes creating universes: any or every black hole might create a universe, regardless of its galaxy's atomic distribution. The black hole's energy has to go somewhere, so suggesting black hole universe creation is contingent on the galaxy's comparative black hole dominance seems unnecessary.
